Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I glance at the clock on the salon wall, my hands deep in the thick, tangled hair of my client. The buildup is worse than I expected, and I know I’ll need extra time to wash and condition before I can even think about cutting. My mind drifts to the home loan repayment looming in two months. Every client, every tip, every minute counts right now. I promised myself I’d pick up extra shifts, maybe squeeze in a few more appointments each week, just to make sure we’re covered. But here I am, running behind schedule, knowing that if I take the time this client’s hair really needs, I’ll fall behind for the rest of the day—and maybe lose out on another walk-in. Yet, if I rush, I risk doing a poor job, losing her trust, and maybe her future business. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations: be the reliable provider my family needs, or the attentive professional my clients expect. I can feel the pressure building, my hands pausing for a moment in her hair, caught between what I owe my family and what I owe my client.
